Certainly. The communication problems between the Prussian commanders were one of the significant factors that affected the outcome of the battle of Koniggratz. During the early stages of the battle, there was a significant disparity in the positioning of different Prussian divisions and some Prussian troops were not aware of the positions of their nearby battalions. Additionally, some of the Prussian commanders were not in direct contact with the overall commander, and their attempts to coordinate their attacks with those of their colleagues were hampered.

The absence of an efficient communication system made it difficult for the Prussian commanders to coordinate their attacks efficiently, causing delays, overlaps, and gaps in the attacks. For example, some Prussian units found themselves attacking unsupported and, therefore, were more vulnerable to the Austrian counter-attacks. Furthermore, the lack of clear communication meant that some Prussian units mistook Austrian fortresses for other units, causing them to direct their attacks in the wrong direction, and thereby worsening the already unfavorable situation. 

Overall, the Prussian army's communication problems during the battle of Koniggratz greatly compromised their ability to coordinate their attacks properly, contributing to their initial setbacks in the battle.
